name: Dum Aloo
history: Dum Aloo is a traditional North Indian dish, particularly popular in Kashmir. It's known for its rich and aromatic gravy, with 'Dum' referring to a slow cooking method using steam.
description: Dum Aloo is a flavorful vegetarian dish consisting of baby potatoes cooked in a rich, creamy, and spicy gravy. The potatoes are usually deep-fried and then simmered in gravy, absorbing the spices and flavors.

equipment.name: pan
equipment.description: For frying potatoes and cooking the gravy.

equipment.name: pressure cooker or pot
equipment.description: For boiling the potatoes, if needed.

instructions.title: Prepare the Potatoes
instructions.description: Boil the baby potatoes until just tender, peel them, and prick them with a fork. Then deep fry until golden brown. Set aside.

instructions.title: Cook the Onion Masala
instructions.description: Heat oil in a pan. Add cumin seeds and let them splutter. Add onions and ginger-garlic paste, cooking until onions turn golden.

instructions.title: Add Spices and Tomato Puree
instructions.description: Add turmeric powder, coriander powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well, then add tomato puree. Cook until oil separates.

instructions.title: Add Yogurt and Cashew Paste
instructions.description: Reduce heat and add whisked yogurt and cashew nut paste. Stir continuously to avoid curdling.

instructions.title: Simmer with Potatoes
instructions.description: Add the fried potatoes and enough water to form a gravy. Cover and simmer on low heat until the gravy thickens.

instructions.title: Finish with Garam Masala
instructions.description: Add garam masala and mix well. Cook for another minute.

instructions.title: Garnish and Serve
instructions.description: Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot with roti or rice.

tips: Ensure the potatoes are not overcooked before frying to maintain their shape.
Stir the yogurt and cashew paste on low heat to prevent the gravy from splitting.
variations: Add green peas or paneer for more texture.
For a smoky flavor, give the dish a 'Dum' by sealing the pan with dough and cooking over low heat.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on the stove or in a microwave until hot.
presentationTips: Serve in a traditional clay pot for an authentic look.
Pair with a side of mint chutney or raita.
